DOC.HEAD: Durenberger: Had `Lapses in Judgment' Over Financial Dealings
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Dave Durenberger said Wednesday his financial dealings did not violate Senate rules, but he apologized for mistakes he made and said he would work to restore public confidence. ``In retrospect, it is clear that I made mistakes and had lapses in judgment on these matters,'' he said at the first of four news conferences planned throughout the state Wednesday. ``I apologize this morning to the people of Minnesota.'' Durenberger, a Republican, said he did not intend to circumvent Senate rules on outside income when he signed a book deal with a Minneapolis publisher, which resulted in his earning $100,000 in outside income over two years. The Senate Ethics Committee is trying to determine whether Durenberger used the book deal to circumvent limits on senators' income from speaking fees. The limit in 1985 was about $22,500; in 1986 it was about $30,000. Durenberger earlier said his appearances were to promote his two books, ``Neither Madmen Nor Messiahs'' and ``Prescription for Change,'' and that he cleared his activity with the Federal Election Commission, which ruled it was allowable compensation. The book deal was one of three plans Durenberger had for boosting his income when he was having financial difficulties. Two of the arrangements are being looked at by the Ethics Committee _ the book matter and allegations that he scheduled speeches in 1985 and 1986 to coincide with appointments he and his wife had with a marriage counselor in Boston. In addition, the Senate Rules Committee is looking into Durenberger charging the Senate for rent at a Minneapolis condominium in which he had a financial interest. Committee aides have said their tentative conclusion was that the matter belonged before the Ethics Committee. Durenberger charged the Senate for rent whenever he stayed at the condo and collected at least $9,947 in expense payments from the Senate for time he spent in Minnesota from July 1983 to June 1987. Durenberger said Wednesday he relied on advice from legal counsel and tax experts, but said he should have paid more attention to the details. The senator also said he has no intention of resigning from the Senate and pledged to work to restore public confidence in him.
